title: Rich Lister gives $20m to Canberra Grammar
text:
"Music in many ways is the pinnacle of the arts because of the skill, commitment and dedication that’s required to make it, and I admire everyone who can play music.

"We’ve all got our different ideas about how we’d like Australia to surge ahead – some of it is through the arts and music, some through sporting challenges or think tanks, or in my case, for the youth of Australia through education."

An artist's rendering of the new music centre. In the 1970s the school's music department was housed in a two-room wooden hut adjacent to playing fields.

In 2013 Mr Snow gave the school $8 million of his own money for a centre for the New Asian Century, as well donating $250,000 from his personal wealth to improve safety in equestrian sport following a double fatality earlier that year.

The music centre will be built largely underground, below historical buildings. In addition to the auditorium, it will include four classrooms, 20 music tuition rooms, a staff room and a 450 square metre library.

In the 1970s the school's music department was housed in a two-room wooden hut in a remote location on the campus.

Head of the school, Justin Garrick, said the new music centre would be positioned at the main entrance of the school.

He said the school's combined primary and senior students contributed to 30 music ensembles and took 330 instrumental tuition classes a week.

"Mr Snow’s exceptional gift will accelerate the school over more than a decade of development, benefiting thousands of current and future students, staff members and families," Dr Garrick said.

"It will place music at the forefront of the school’s educational experience, and it will emphasise the centrality of learning, research and study.

"The centre will give not just the school, but the Canberra community an outstanding learning facility, meeting space, conference venue, concert hall and community resource for music that will make the school more intrinsic than ever to the educational and cultural life of Australia’s capital."

The next largest donation given to a school by an old boy was a $10 million bequest to Melbourne Grammar School by pastoralist Jack Morrow in the 1990s.

The Snow family made its wealth with Canberra property development and in 1998 bought the lease of the aviation facilities, land and infrastructure at Canberra Airport, including development rights.
description: A former student has made the largest biggest donation to a school for a music centre and scholarships for indigenous Australians.
